awd_titl_txt: Scholarship Support for Richard Tapia Diversity in Computing Conferences
awd_abstract_narration:
The Association for Computing Machinery's Richard Tapia Celebration of Diversity in Computing is one of the premier venues to acknowledge, promote and celebrate diversity in all parts of the computing field.  This project will provide scholarships for the next three years of the conference. Scholarships will facilitate attendance of undergraduate and graduate students; faculty from minority-serving institutions will attend and participate in conference activities, and a Doctoral Consortium will provide PhD students with group and one-on-one interactions with leaders in the field of computing.  The intellectual merit of this project is in the stimulating environment and knowledge provided by the excellent presentations and activities associated with the conference. The broader impact will consist largely in the connections made by the scholarship recipients with other attendees at the conference and with the entire breadth of the computer science field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project is to support participants from the following groups to the Richard Tapia Diversity in Computing Conferences, which is generally held in the mid-September time frame.  The grant supports the following scholarships:

  • Student Scholarships, to support undergraduate and graduate students from underrepresented communities -- African-Americans/Blacks, Hispanics, Native Americans/Indigeneous Americans, People with Disabilities, and Women
  • MSI Faculty Scholarships, to support faculty from Minority Serving Institutions
  • Doctoral Student Scholarships, to support doctoral students participating in the Doctoral Consortium

The Richard Tapia Conference is the main conference that highlights the diversity that exists in computing.  The conference mission is to bring together undergraduate and graduate students, professionals, and faculty in computer science and computer engineering from all backgrounds and ethnicities to:

  • Celebrate the diversity that currently exists in computer science and computer engineering.
  • Connect with others with common backgrounds, ethnicities, disabilities, and gender so as to create communities that extend beyond the conference.
  • Receive advice from and make useful contacts with computer science and computer engineering leaders in academia and industry.
  • Be inspired by great presentations and conversations with successful people in computer science and computer engineering who have similar backgrounds, ethnicities, disabilities, and gender to the attendees.

During the time period of 09/01/2022 - 08/31/2023, Tapia 2022 took place on September 7-10 in Washington, DC. The funding from NSF grant was used to support scholarships for 100 students from underrepresented communities, 9 participants in the Doctoral Consortium (DC) along with the food and A/V for DC, and three faculty from MSIs.  As Tapia 2022 was the first in-person conference since Tapia 2019, scholarship recipients were placed in individual rooms to address concerns of rooming with others.

The conference consisted of 1800 attendees, with the following demographics:

  • 22% Black or African American
  • 12% Hispanic/Latinx
  • 1% Native American/Pacific Islander/Native Alaskan/American Indian
  • 7% Multiracial
  • 8% People with Disabilities

In terms of gender, the conference included:

  • 56% female
  • 52% male
  • 2% non-binary

In terms of attendees, the conference included:

  • 35% undergraduate students
  • 15% master's students
  • 8% PhD students
  • 17% faculty
  • 5% government
  • 16% industry/professionals
  • 4% other

The following results were taken from the conference survey, with a 30% response rate:

  • 82% rate the conference as very good or outstanding
  • 77% made professional connections during the conference
  • 74% made informal connections
  • 54% was able to get advice from peers

In terms of the survey results particular to students:

  • 91% agreed or strongly agreed that the conference was inspiring with respect to learning about various opportunities in computing
  • 83% agreed or strongly agreed that attending Tapia 2022 increased their dedication to completing their degree in computing
  • 91% agreed or strongly agreed that attending Tapia 2022 provided an opportunity to make new connections

The survey results indicate the impact of the Tapia Conference on the participants, especially the students.


Last Modified: 01/13/2024
Modified by: Valerie E Taylor
